name: The Dig®
description: An asteroid the size of a small moon is on a crash course toward Earth. Once the wayward asteroid is nuked into a safe orbit, a trio conducts a routine examination of the rocky surface. What they uncover is anything but routine.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or Vista Processor: Any 2002 era PC or better Memory: 32 MB RAM Graphics: 2 MB - PCI Graphics Card DirectX®: Required for sound Hard Drive: 650 MB Sound: 16-bit sound card

reviews.review_text: A legendary game, yet one of LucasArts' lesser known pieces due to its somewhat-awkward presentation. The DIG started as an idea by Steven Spielbeg that he soon abandoned with nowhere to take it, handing it over to his friend George Lucas' studio to make something out of it. What they created was something magical. An odyssey into space and the man's determination to survive and explore.  Playing as the aging astronaut Commander Boston Low, you must traverse a strange and marvellously deadened world beyond our reach, of a planet long abandoned by most of its former inhabitants. Joined by his two crewmates being the severe reporter Maggie Robbins and the cool-minded geologist Ludger Brink, Boston must use his natural survival instincts and quick-witted skills of human engineering to try and formulate a way to escape, explore, and uncover the origins of this mysterious planet, and how they must find their way back home.  While the DIG may not be LucasArts' best work by far, it is certainly not one you should miss if you love their library. The graphics are not the best, being that while the LucasArts style works well for more cartoony games such as Sam & Max or Monkey Island, it's a little more uncertain to do so with actual human characters and as a result they can look rather off during cutscenes. Like 'monkeys wearing human masks' off.  Nevertheless the rest of the game shines through with its pure atmosphere. The graphics for its weird alien backgrounds are gorgeous, the sound design is just absolutely at the top of its game more than ever from LucasArts with roaring waves, howling winds, deep resonance within space and the most oddest of creatures wallowing and shrieking from all around you.  The dialogue is rather snarky in about 80% of its places but that only makes it more fun with the likes of Steve Blum and Robert Patrick delivering the most deadpan of deliveries. The puzzles are...infamous to say the least and in truth one or two of them could have been much better designed. I'll give you a hint for free, the head of the skeleton is not meant to be on the top left, but bottom right.  Regardless, I say go ahead if you love LucasArts' work, and try out this gem from the past that, while is a little rough around the edges and is perhaps at the lower end of their library, is nevertheless one worthy of playing if you are a fan of such games.

The Dig is one of the best science fiction games ever created, maybe even one of the best science fiction stories ever told. Sure it's a dated game, but in my personal opinion the story is what counts. The puzzles offer some difficult challenges to the player. If you can't figure out a puzzle, by all means, use the internet (It's better than complaining how you spent countless hours because you suck at the game.) The soundtrack was created by Michael Land, and it is definitely one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard.   As for the 'Outdated feel' of the game, I wouldn't let that sort of thing bother me since it's full of AMAZING and UNIQUE layouts, backgrounds, characters and creatures. The cast is brilliant. Robert Patrick (T-1000 from T2) lent his voice talent as Boston Lowe. You get some great one-liners any classic and true Lucasarts fan would hold dear to their heart.  This game is amazing. I would love to see it as a film some day.

I remember playing this game with my brothers back in the day, when I saw it was available on Steam I got pretty excited and played it through in one afternoon. I did have to look at a walkthrough a couple times, not sure how we managed to beat this as kids. Fun game, great story, difficult puzzles and lots of good memories for me.

The Dig is one of Lucasarts' less known and less succesful point and click adventure games. Unlike most of their comedic fare, this one's played entirely straight; a sci-fi story of exploration and solving puzzles. The interface is very simple, no 'use, look, pick up, etc' commands, just a simple choice between interacting or examining. Despite that, it can be pretty challenging at times and even have you stumped for a good while.  Good: fantastic music, seasoned voice actors (Robert Patrick, Steven Blum), nicely painted backgrounds, challenging puzzles, good gameplay length and some lovely animated cutscenes.  Bad: at times frustrating, dialogue can be kind of stilted and will endlessly repeat as you try to solve puzzles, simple interface makes for less creative adventure gaming, low res sprites, and two or three puzzles that will really send you runing for gamefaqs.  Overall: still a great classic. Avoid a walkthrough as much as you can and you'll definitely enjoy the experience!

Really cool to play this game again! Loved it from before and loving it now. Just a word to anyone experiencing the F1 or F5 bug, i know its been said before but simply minimize back to windowed mode (Alt+Enter) then save and go back. Easy peasy lemon squeezy!

The best adventure gamer ever created. Seriously.  Si os gustan las novelas de ciencia ficción este es el mejor exponente que podréis encontrar. Una historia que os cautivará, con puzzles difíciles (como se hacían antaño los juegos) y una música sobrecogedora.  Si no lo jugasteis en su día, hacedlo ahora, por favor.
Just a great game, it ages very well actually and plays without problem on a modern pc.  Here's a tip: google UHS for 'spoiler free' hints. You will probably need them.

Some of the puzzles made me want to punch a kitten, but the writing was tight and I enjoyed the nostalgia for a time of gaming I'd never been part of.   Lots and lots of walking and clicking and going but WHY at random pieces.   But also entertaining dialogue, a plot that's more or less coherent, and a satisfying conclusion.

One of the very first games I played way back when. I love Lucasarts pointandclick games and even though the story never changes, I've replayed them over and over again. Storyline is engaging, characters are well done and the soundtrack is fitting and atmospheric. One gripe is a massive plothole at the end, one of the character's apperance changes dramatically and that isn't explained in the game. I have read the book version of this game and it is explained in there though.

Anyone who has been gaming for 20 years knows of the age of VGA adventure games. The dig is an amazing sci-fi adventure game, all mouse controlled.  Uncover alien secrets on an asteroid that turns out not to be an asteroid... Some good puzzles and great dialogue are found within and Is a must have for Kings Quest/ police quest/ space quest/ leisure suit larry(dos) fans. This plays just like you remember it.

This game was overlooked by the adventure game community because it is a little more serious than the most popular games.  It is totally worth your time.  A little weak at times and viciously difficult in places it stands up as one of the better gaming experiences you can have within this genre.  Plus, it has Robert Patrick.

The Dig is a hard game to recommend. This is not to say that it is without its merits, as there are a great many things it does quite well. The game’s opening is effective and catching with a wonderful sense of mystery and foreboding. As the story progresses, the plot does take some odd turns but I found I enjoyed it. And it must be stated that even late into the game the art direction is fantastic and settings feel alien and strange.  That said, there are some big issues holding The Dig back: namely the puzzles. After the opening segment, the puzzles quickly dive into nearly incomprehensible territory. A great many of them are just frustrating and lacking any sort of direction or hints. While this may be intentional, as exploring an alien world without guidance would undoubtedly be trying, it doesn’t make for a fun game.  Overall, The Dig does have virtues but they are obscured by some terrible puzzle design. I’d recommend the game only if one is exceptionally patient or willing to use a walkthrough.
i liked the orinal gane but has not dated well
It's classic shovelware, that's why it's called 'The Dig'
Great puzzles that stack up against most games out today, engaging story and visuals that that were ahead of their time.

This was a game I always remember seeing when I was a bit younger, sure it was shown on Bad Influence or Gamesmaster and I thought it looked incredible and Stephen Spielberg's name was mentioned in line with it. So after about 15 years I finally got the chance to play it through, it really did capture me. Transported me right back into the old school of point and click adventures. I spent 17 hours on this game it says, there were a few moments I just got lost, I never looked at FAQ hence why the time is SO long. Characters are all voiced very well and the story had a good pace to it. Highly recommended.

Definitely my all time favorite point and click adventure.  Sci-fi theme, well written story, nice voice acting, a phenomenal soundtrack, very intuitive puzzles, all in one title.  A must own in my opinion.

Yes. Yes yes yes yes yes. I've been meaning to play this game for twenty years. I had the demo back in the day but it wouldn't run on my computer at the time.  I decided it was finally time to jump back in and boy--was it worth the wait.  The game is done in the storied Lucas Arts adventure game style which works perfectly for this piece of Steven Speilberg sci-fi. If you're a young pup and you don't know what this means (i.e., you haven't played Curse of Monkey Island, Full Throttle, Day of the Tentacle, Sam and Max, etc.) you may want to watch a Let's Play or something to make sure you understand what kind of game this is. As a whole, these kinds of games have trouble 'holding up over the years' in that they are very different than most games today. For folks who are familiar with the genre, this is a shining example.  The art is great. The music is fantastic. The dialog is charming (written by Orson Scot Card of Ender's Game fame).  The budget was obviously large for this game as it was clearly put together with a lot of care. Stunning use of cinematography to draw attention to the features of awe-inspiring alien landscapes and technology.  I hate puzzles in games. I'm just not a puzzle game guy. Most of the puzzles in this game are very approachable. I suggest giving them a whack but not being too proud to consult a walkthrough if you are getting frustrated. I did do this myself in a few places where the 'adventure game logic' was spread a little too thinly and to save myself unnecessary walking around once I knew what I was supposed to do.  I spent six hours enchanted by the characters and the story. Well worth what I paid for this game.  Edit: Don't forget to use Alt-Enter to force the game into full screen. F1 is your menu where you can turn on subtitles and save your game.  Edit edit: You can also double-click on most location labels to quickly jump from screen to screen. You don't have to stand there and wait for Boston to walk across the screen.

I was unable to play this game when it was orignally released, because simply I was a pre-teen with no job and no money :P. After 10 long years I finally bought it and thourghly enjoyed it. LucasArts did know how to make adventure games. Other titles I would recommend by LucasArts would be Full Throttle and the Monkey Island series.
For me, this marked the moment LucasArts game started going downhill. Still pretty good, tho.
If you like point and click adventures, adventures, stories, or games, you owe it to yourself to play this classic.

My favorite point-and-click adventure game. Also, one of the greatest stories I've ever seen in any video game. Spielberg had a hand in the story, it was originally going to be made into a film. It would have been too expensive to turn into a movie, so they made a game. The dialog and the music are both fantastic , and they still hold up today. Gameplay is fun and rewarding. Some puzzles and solutions are a little cryptic, so you may want to check an online walkthrough every now and again.

Click and point ceribral thinking our of the box games like this is the reason my childhood lives on. If you don't like games like this then you are the reason crap 3rd party shooters dominate the market. A movieesque journey you can never top!

This is a very unsusal game when compared to what Lucasarts was making at the time; it was a very adult style game, unlike the pure comedy style of adventure games that they were making at the time. You control Boston Low (voiced by Robert Patrick from Terminator 2 - he played the T-1000) and you along with 2 others are accidently transported to an alien world that has long been abandoned. In typical point and click style, you must guide Boston around the ruins to find a way home - and to discover the deadly secret that drove the once advanced civilization to ruin. If you like adventure games then this classic is well worth giving a go.

I loved this game, got it a long time ago in a lucas arts game pack, bought it so its on the library for a nostalgia trip. its up there with indiana jones: fate of atlantis, day of the tentical, sam and max hit the road, and monkey island! I recomend the book too!
A good old Lucas Arts Adventure.  Interesting sci-fi and discovering theme, it will turn a bit in a thriller.  Suggested for the good old passionate adventure gamers.
Most Point and Click fans have definitely played this one by now, but if you haven't then give it a try-The main character is voiced by the dude who played the T-1000 in Terminator 2.

I had a lot of fun playing The Dig. For the most part, it's a simple adventure game, but this title was a big-budget game for its time, and it shows. This game is fully voice-acted, which was incredibly rare at the time. The voice-acting and graphics are done very well. It's a bit slow at first, but it's pretty interesting once it picks up.  This is definitely the shining star in the LucasArts Adventure Pack. I certainly played it enough to get $5 worth of entertainment.
Absolutely a classic, still waiting on a movie being made.

After playing through this game all the way through and remembering the times I would play it with my dad when I was little, I honestly have to say that this is one of my favorite video games ever. It has one of the greatest stories I have ever gone through, and the style of the graphics is just superb. I would highly, highly recommend this game to anyone. I really hope I can see this game get the attention it really deserves. Definitely give it a try.
That 'Bruce Willis vs. a meteor' movie + Rendezvous with Rama. And it's an adventure game by Lucas Arts.
Good ol lucasarts point and click adventure with great musical parts.
A truely timeless game, stands up well to this day and plays naturally. Immersive storyline and artwork that makes playing this game a pleasure to this day. Still a favourite.

A great game all in all, it has fluid animations that IMO have aged pretty well, an engaging story, and interesting character arcs. But it's pretty hard. The main reason I won was because of hints given to me while I was streaming the game, but even then it took me a while to figure things out. Very easy to recommend unless you aren't experienced with point and clicks, in which case I'd direct you to LucasArts' other games like Monkey Island or Sam & Max.  I give it 6.5/7 rods.

I LOVE THIS GAME.  I've read many peoples comments both for and against. I remember this game from my child hood and it's got all the apeal to me now as then. the music score is a thing of great beauty and the simple point and click is so much fun for the kids to sit and watch as it plays almost like a cartoon for them, I remember the puzzels well enough from my childhood which helps. to me it felt short after just completing it in 4.7 hours. WITH-OUT any walkthrough.  Anyway, some of the puzzels can get a first time player feeling stuck, so always explore and look around sooner or later you find the one thing you may have over looked.  I give this game an 8.5 out of ten, partly due to fond memorys.  get it play it and enjoy such a unque game.
One of the best games i've ever played
Best with ScummVM mod
So glad bought this masterpiece
Surprisingly good point 'n click game. Very good story, good pixel art, good voice acting... everything was really good!
